justification: The article states, "Impulsive action ... is usually measured by Stop Signal Tasks (SST)."
It notes that impulsive action "is usually measured by ... Go/No-Go paradigms (GNG), requiring the inhibition of a dominant behavioral reaction."
"Common measures of impulsive choice include delay discounting tasks such as the Monetary Choice Questionnaire (MCQ)."
The same sentence lists the "Iowa Gambling Task (IGT)" as a computerized gambling task used for impulsive choice.
The article adds that impulsive choice is also measured by "the Cambridge Gambling Task (CGT), capturing decision-making under risk."
In Methods it says, "The Go/No-Go Task (GNG) is a computerized measure of response inhibition ... (i.e., automatic inhibition)."
The Methods section describes the SST as "a stop-signal paradigm examining action cancellation (i.e., controlled inhibition)."
It specifies, "The Iowa Gambling Task (IGT) is a computerized neurocognitive task that examines decision-making under ambiguity."
"The Cambridge Gambling Task (CGT) is a computerized neurocognitive task that measures decision-making under risk."
"The Monetary Choice Questionnaire (MCQ) is a 27-item forced choice measure ... that examines delay discounting."
